For VOCs oxidation technology, significant room for enhancement still exists in terms of catalytic performance of commonly used transition metal oxide-based catalysts. In this work, we designed MnFeOx oxides catalysts by using in situ pyrolysis of MnFe bimetallic MOF-74 as efficient and stable catalysts for toluene oxidation and this bimetallic framework was synthesized by metal doping. The preferred Mn2Fe3Ox-500 (Mn/Fe molar ratio of 2:3, calcination T=500 °C) catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic activity and stability towards toluene which was significantly superior the control MnOx-500 catalyst. Under simulated industrial real-exhaust conditions, the Mn2Fe3Ox-500 catalyst maintained better resistance at higher air velocities, in addition to exhibiting excellent stability and good water resistance. The superior toluene oxidation activity of Mn2Fe3Ox-500 catalyst can be associated with its high reducibility of metal active species, abundance of oxygen species, and the well dispersion of Fe2O3 and MnOx species. In addition, suggested potential degradation pathways for toluene over the Mn2Fe3Ox-500 catalyst. For the exhaust gas purification industry, this work will be beneficial in exploring the mechanistic level of MOF materials in the field of VOCs removal. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Metal-organic frameworks MnFeOx toluene oxidation stability water resistance Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Haze pollution is increasingly become a major threat to the global environment [1]. Hazy weather has a significant correlation with PM2.5 (aerosol particles with diameter <2.5 μm) and ozone concentrations, while volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are important contributors to the increase in atmospheric concentrations of pollutants such as ozone, as well as their conversion to secondary organic particulate matter, and ultimately the formation of PM2.5. Namely, VOCs, ozone and PM2.5 are interrelated [2]. In addition, VOCs have direct toxic effects on humans through the respiratory, dermal, and digestive tracts, and can also cause acute or chronic poisoning. The emission of VOCs poses a huge menace and nonreversible harm to the global environment [3]. Among them, toluene, as a widely used organic chemical material, is often present in industrial activities such as chemicals, paints, transportation and paper making. At present, large quantities of toluene generated by human activities are volatilized directly into the atmosphere, causing negative impacts on both the environment and human body [4]. Therefore, efficient removal technologies for VOCs have received considerable attention in recent years. Multiple technical methods currently applied to control the emission of VOCs, such as photocatalytic degradation, biological methods, low-temperature plasma treatment, and catalytic oxidation [5]. Among the many feasible technologies, catalytic oxidation is highly expected not only for its high removal efficiency and energy efficiency, but also for its low operating temperature and product toxicity [6]. The efficient catalyst is an urgent need for catalytic oxidation technology. In general, noble metals and metal oxides are commonly selected for the catalytic oxidation of VOCs [7]. But the expensive cost, high temperature deactivation and low resistance to water limit their large-scale industrial application [8]. Metal oxide catalysts (Cu-based, Mn-based, Ce-based, Co-based, etc.) have been recognized as a promising alternative due to the availability, higher thermal stability and toxicity resistance [9]. Although much work has been done in the development of metal oxide catalysts, their catalytic activity and stability remain challenges in effectively removing VOCs. In the study of noble metal catalysts, the metal particle size is related to the activity of the catalyst for VOCs, which has been widely confirmed [10]. Cañón et al. [11] synthesized CoMnMgAl-Ox catalysts for toluene oxidation, in which the prevalence of small particle size Co (III) species enabled the catalysts with better performance. Wang et al. [4] employed different methods to synthesize Ag-loaded MOF-derived CeO2 for toluene oxidation, different synthesis methods affected the particle size of Ce, which in turn affected the specific surface area, chemical composition, and catalytic performance of the catalysts. Small particle size and high dispersibility of the active component contribute to catalytic activity, thus reducing the catalyst cost. Metal oxides can be alternative catalysts to precious metals due to their low price and good low temperature activity. Unfortunately, metal oxide catalysts prepared by traditional loading methods inevitably obtained by calcination of precursor, which makes catalyst particles aggregate into larger blocks. Insufficient exposure of the active site of large particles leads to decreased activity. Therefore, the development of small and stable metal oxide catalysts to effectively remove VOCs is still an important strategy. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are constructed of inorganic nodes connected with organic ligands by coordination bonds (or other intermolecular forces), which have the advantages of diversified structure, high chemical stability and large specific surface area, now they have been successfully applied in heterogeneous catalysis of wastewater, gas adsorption and separation, energy storage, substance detection and adsorption and electrochemistry etc. [12]. Liu et al. [13] used MOF-BTC as a carrier to prepare Pt/MOF-BTC catalyst with abundant platinum atoms and oxygen vacancies, which promoted toluene degradation. Gu et al. [14] prepared core-shell Co-MOF-74@Mn-MOF-74 catalysts for toluene oxidation which exhibited high benzaldehyde selectivity (98.1 %) and toluene conversion (22.4 %). However, with appropriate pyrolysis conditions, MOFs derived metal oxides can better retain some of the properties of MOFs precursor [15]. Moreover, the mixed oxides prepared by using MOFs as precursor can be modified with heteroatoms at the molecular level to facilitate catalytic reactions [16,17]. Herein, MnFe-MOF-74 precursors were prepared by targeted anchoring of Fe species on the basis of Mn-MOF, and the performance of their derived catalysts was evaluated for the removal of toluene. The bimetallic MnFe-MOF-74 derived catalysts exhibited high catalytic degradation of toluene under simulated exhaust conditions. A series of physicochemical characterization methods were used to analyze the structural property changes, determine the optimal preparation conditions, investigate the key factors affecting the efficient degradation of toluene pollutants, and probe the degradation mechanism on the catalyst surface. This work illustrated that appropriate Fe doping was conducive to the catalytic degradation of VOCs by MnFe-MOF-74 derived catalysts. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemical materials Manganese chloride (MnCl2·4H2O), ferrous chloride (FeCl2·4H2O), N, N-Dimethylformamide (C3H7NO), ethanol absolute (C2H6O) and methanol (CH4O) belong to Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. 2, 5-Dihydroxyterephthalic acid (C8H6O6) was bought from Macklin. 2.2 Sample preparation In this experiment, MnFe-MOF-74 were prepared by solvothermal method (Fig. 1 a). Taking Mn2Fe3-MOF-74 as an example: 0.26 g MnCl2·4H2O, 0.392 g FeCl2·4H2O and 0.15 g 2, 5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid (DHTP) were dissolve in 50 mL mixed solution of N, N-Dimethylformamide (DMF): ethanol = 15:1 (volume ratio). Then, the well-mixed solution was quickly transferred to an autoclave and reacted in an oven at 150 °C for 12 h. Typically, the reactor was cooled to room temperature, and the separated solid samples were washed with methanol at least three times. Finally, Mn2Fe3-MOF-74 was obtained by drying in an oven at 60 °C for 12 h. The ratio of MnFe-MOF-74 was also optimized with Mn/Fe molar ratios of 3:1, 3:2, 1:1, 2:3 and 1:3, the total amount of Mn and Fe was kept at 4.3 mol. The corresponding metal oxides obtained from high temperature pyrolysis of MnFe-MOF-74 with different Mn/Fe molar ratios were named as Mn3Fe1Ox, Mn3Fe2Ox, Mn1Fe1Ox, Mn2Fe3Ox and Mn1Fe3Ox. Mn2Fe3-MOF-74 calcined at 300 °C was named Mn2Fe3Ox-300, and materials obtained at other temperatures were named according to the same principle. The synthesis of Fe-MOF-74 and Mn-MOF-74 was similar to that described above, with the difference being the addition of FeCl2 only or MnCl2 only (molar ratio of FeCl2/MnCl2:C8H6O6= 4.3:1). The metal oxides obtained by pyrolysis of Fe-MOF-74 and Mn-MOF-74 at 500 °C were named FeOx-500 and MnOx-500, respectively. 2.3 Material characterization The X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis were performed in a Bruker D8 Advance with CuKα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) and the XRD spectrum was recorded within 5–80o (2θ). The morphologies and elements distribution were recorded on a scanning electron microscopy (SEM, ZEISS Gemini 300) with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS, Smartedx, OXFORD XPLORE30). To acquire the information of microstructures and the particle size distribution, high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM, JEOL JEM2100F) was carried out. The Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (FT-IR, TRTracer-100) equipped with a liquid N2-cooled MCT detector was employed to obtain the FT-IR spectra. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific K-Alpha) was used for valence states of element analysis. Temperature-programmed reduction in hydrogen (H2-TPR), and Temperature-programmed desorption of oxygen (O2-TPD) were conducted on Builder PCA-1200 equipment. Bruker INVENIO S equipment was used to conduct in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (in-situ DRIFTS) experiments. 2.4 Catalytic activity evaluation The catalytic activity of catalysts was evaluated using gas chromatography (GC) analysis. Load 0.15 g sample into a fixed reaction bed with an inner diameter of 6 mm. Gas composition: 1000 ppm toluene, 20 vol.% O2 and N2 (total 100 ml). Weight hourly space velocity (WHSV): 40,000 mL/(g h). The entire test regime was always conducted under environmental pressure. Toluene concentrations were monitored by GC9790II (Fuli, Zhejiang), which was equipped with a flame ionization detector. The degradation rate of toluene was calculated according to Eq. (1). (1) Tolu ene conv ersi on ( % ) = 1 − C Tolu ene ( out ) / C Tolu ene ( in ) × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure and morphology of catalysts The XRD spectrum of Fe-MOF-74, Mn-MOF-74 and MnFe-MOF-74 were similar to the standard spectra, with two strong diffraction peaks at 2θ = 6.924o and 11.956o, corresponding to (210) and (300) crystal planes of MOF-74, respectively [18]. It indicated that the crystal structure of MOF-74 was well maintained after Fe doping (Fig. 1b). After calcination at 500 °C, the characteristic diffraction peaks of MOF-74 completely disappeared, indicating that the structure of MOF-74 collapsed at high temperature (Fig. 1c). For Mn-MOF-74 derived samples, there were obvious diffraction peaks at 2θ = 32.9o, 23.1o, 55.1o, 65.7o, 49.3o, 38.2o and 45.1o, corresponding to the (222), (211), (440), (622), (431), (400) and (332) crystal planes of Mn2O3 (JCPDS No. 41-1442). While for FeOx-500 and MnFeOx-500, the characteristic peaks at 2θ = 24.1o, 33.2o, 40.9o, 49.5o, 54.1o, 62.5o and 64.0o, corresponding to the (012), (104), (113), (024), (116) crystal planes of Fe2O3 (JCPDS No. 33-0664). Notably, no obvious diffraction peaks attributed to Mn species appeared in the XRD pattern of Mn2Fe3Ox-500, which may indicate that Mn species existed in the form of amorphous and highly dispersed, or Mn atom into the lattice of the iron oxide to form solid solutions, which agreed very well with the results of HRTEM and the relevant literature [19]. Based on the XRD patterns, it can be judged that the structure of MOF-74 was not changed after Fe doping, but changed the active species and dispersion of its derivatives. FTIR analysis was used to analyze the chemical structure (Fig. 2 ). The positions of the absorption peaks of Fe-MOF-74, Mn-MOF-74 and Mn2Fe3-MOF-74 could almost completely overlap (Fig. 2a). At ∼ 1653 cm−1, the absorption peak was the stretching vibration of carboxylate (–COO) from organic ligand DHTP. The band at ∼ 1629 cm−1 was caused by the stretching vibration of C=O from solvent DMF. The absorption peaks at ∼ 1552 and 1399 cm−1 were the telescopic vibrations of mononuclear aromatic C=C, which belong to the skeletal vibrations of benzene ring, indicating the involvement of organic ligand DHTP in the synthesis of MOF-74. The absorption peak produced by the vibrational of C–N bond in solvent DMF appeared at ∼ 1237 cm−1, indicating that solvent DMF was adsorbed on the catalyst surface or inside the pore channel. At ∼ 1198 cm−1, the absorption peak belong to the stretching vibrational of the C–O single bond. In the benzene ring of the organic ligand, the absorption peaks at ∼ 881 and 810 cm−1 represent the in-plane and out-of-plane vibrations of C–H, respectively. The adsorption peaks at ∼ 574 and 461 cm−1 were the vibrational of M–O bonds. FTIR results demonstrated that MnFe-MOF-74 has been successfully synthesized, and the doping of Fe did not change the crystal structure of the MOF-74. Fig. 2b showed the FTIR spectra of FeOx-500, MnOx-500 and Mn2Fe3Ox-500. The absorption peaks at 470–680 cm−1 in the catalyst were the stretching and bending vibrations of the M–O bond or the M–O–M bond [20]. Both peaks at ∼ 1123 and 1140 cm−1 belong to the M–O bend, and the peak at this position becomes slightly weaker with the doping of Fe. The desorption of surface lattice oxygen (Olatt) arises from the breaking of unsaturated metal-oxygen bonds [21]. Weakened M-O bond can cause an increase in surface lattice oxygen activity and redox properties, all of which are inextricably linked to the enhancement of the performance of the catalyst [22]. FTIR results confirmed that Mn2Fe3Ox-500 had a weaker M-O bond, which in turn confirms that the Fe doping gives the catalyst better catalytic oxidation performance. To specifically reveal the microscopic morphology, the samples were analyzed by SEM, EDS and HRTEM. As shown in Fig. 3 a, Mn-MOF had a typical rod-like structure with a flat surface and a length of about 9–13 μm. After calcination at 500 °C, MnOx-500 showed a small volume shrinkage, the rod-like form fractured and the material surface became rough and porous (Fig. 3b). After Fe doping, the Mn2Fe3-MOF-74 still retained its rod-like morphology, the surface became rough, and the overall stacking distribution was significantly reduced in volume, with a length of about 0.1–0.65 μm (Fig. 3c). The morphology of Mn2Fe3Ox-500 prepared by Mn2Fe3-MOF-74 calcination changed considerably and consisted of irregular nanoparticle stacks. In addition, a large number of nanopores were formed in the process of MOF calcination (Fig. 3d), which was conducive to the mass transfer of the reaction gas on Mn2Fe3Ox-500. SEM-EDS mapping of Mn2Fe3Ox-500 confirmed the presence of Mn, Fe, O, and C, indicating that Fe was indeed successfully doped into MnFe-MOF-74 and the generated composite metal oxides through calcination. It also verifies the conjecture that the non-detection of manganese oxides in XRD was attributed to the solid solution formation of Mn in the crystals. Fig. 3e,f showed the TEM images of Mn2Fe3Ox-500. In addition, it was worth noting that the HRTEM image of Mn2Fe3Ox-500 showed two distinct lattice fringes (spacing =0.25 and 0.36 nm), which was attributed to lattice spacing of (110) plane and (012) plane of Fe2O3, respectively [23]. Interestingly, no lattice fringe belonging to Mn oxides was found. According to the relevant literature, Mn may be present in an amorphous form or entered into the lattice of Fe2O3 as a solid solution [24]. To reveal the dispersion of Mn and Fe in Mn2Fe3Ox-500, we used TEM to apply EDS to map the presence of different metals, which observed that Mn and Fe are well dispersed. In addition, TEM-EDS analysis also confirmed that Mn and Fe species existed in Mn2Fe3Ox-500, which were in a highly dispersed state (Fig. 3(g–j)). Introducing another metal element would result in an increase in the dispersion of Mn species, and similar arguments have been made in studies by other scholars [25,26]. 3.2 Catalytic elimination of toluene In practical applications, the catalytic activity of the VOCs catalysts needs to maintain superior at low temperature, which is an extremely important. In this work, the typical pollutant toluene as the main target, and the catalytic activity of the sample was studied under the different conditions. The temperatures for toluene conversions of 10 %, 50 % and 90 % are denoted as T 10, T 50 and T 90. In Fig. 4 a, when the reaction temperature was below 200 °C, there was no significant difference in the conversion of toluene by various catalysts, and the conversion of toluene was below 10 %. With the increase of temperature, the difference of toluene conversion for different ratios of catalysts became progressively more apparent. Overall, the catalytic oxidation activity of monometallic MOF-derived FeOx-500 and MnOx-500 catalysts for toluene was poor, the T 90 for FeOx-500 and MnOx-500 catalysts were 321 °C and 256°C, respectively. The doping amount of Fe species in MnFeOx catalyst affected its performance. When the molar ratio of Mn: Fe was 2:3, the Mn2Fe3Ox-500 performed best with T 50, T 90 of 216 and 220 °C, respectively, which were 34 and 36 °C lower than the corresponding temperatures of MnOx-500. It was noteworthy that even at a low load with a molar ratio of Mn: Fe = 3: 1, Fe doping can still contribute significantly to the catalytic performance of MnFeOx. After determining the optimal metal composition, the different calcination temperatures (300–600 °C), a major factor affecting the catalyst performance, are also worth exploring (Fig. 4b). Mn2Fe3Ox-300, Mn2Fe3Ox-400 and Mn2Fe3Ox-500 catalysts showed higher conversion of toluene with increasing reaction temperature. Among them, Mn2Fe3Ox-500 exhibited best, the conversion rate of 1000 ppm toluene attained 90 % at 220 °C. The catalytic activity of Mn2Fe3Ox-300 and Mn2Fe3Ox-400 had little difference, both reaching 90 % toluene conversion at 250 °C, while the toluene conversion of Mn2Fe3Ox-600 at 246 °C was only 10 %. Therefore, the calcination temperature of 500 °C was chosen for the preparation of Mn2Fe3Ox-500 catalyst. In view of practical applications, the effect of different WHSV on the performance of Mn2Fe3Ox-500 catalyst for toluene was investigated. In Fig. 4c, when WHSV = 40,000 mL/(g h), the performance of T 50 and T 90 was 216 and 220 °C, respectively, which was similar to that of WHSV = 60,000 mL/(g h) (T 50= 209 °C, T 90= 219 °C). When the WHSV was reduced to 30,000 mL/(g h), T 90 was 19 °C lower than the corresponding temperature of 40,000 mL/(g h). However, when the WHSV was increased 4 times, the T 90 changed from 201 to 251 °C. The lower the WHSV value, the longer the residence time of toluene on the catalyst surface and the more thorough the contact with the activated species, which was the reason for the catalytic enhancement. 3.3 Stability and water resistance of catalysts The stability and reusability of the catalyst require further investigation. In Fig. 5 a, the toluene conversion of MnOx-500 at 250°C remained constant over 36 h. Mn2Fe3Ox-500 could maintain the conversion rate of 90 % at its optimum reaction temperature (220 °C) for 36 h in a continuous reaction, indicating that the MOF derived catalytic materials had excellent stability, which was conducive to practical application. Mn2Fe3Ox-500 showed good reproducibility in three consecutive degradations of toluene with similar conversion rates (Fig. 5b). In practical industrial applications, catalysts are forced to consider the negative impact that water vapor can have on catalyst performance. When feed gas contained water vapor, the catalytic activity and stability were reduced, mainly due to competitive negative effects [27]. Here, Fig. 5c showed the catalytic oxidation performance of MnOx-500 and Mn2Fe3Ox-500 on toluene in the absence/presence of 5 and 10 vol.% H2O. The toluene conversion of MnOx-500 was at 80 % at 250 °C after water vapor was cut off, then in the presence of 5 and 10 vol.% H2O, the performance dropped to 65 % and 55 % respectively. After stopping H2O injection, the toluene conversion could gradually return to 75 % after a certain period of time, indicating that the effect of water vapor was irreversible. Surprisingly, under high humidity conditions (10 vol.% H2O vapor), the toluene conversion of Mn2Fe3Ox-500 at 220°C remained almost unaffected at over 90 %. After water vapor testing and stability testing, there was no significant change in the functional groups on the surface of the Mn2Fe3Ox-500 catalyst (Fig. 5d). In all, Mn2Fe3Ox-500 performed well in terms of catalytic activity, stability, and water resistance. 3.4 Catalytic mechanism and reaction pathway of VOCs degradation FeOx-500, MnOx-500 and Mn2Fe3Ox-500 catalysts were studied by XPS analysis to analyze the surface element valence and species (Fig. 6 ). In the complete XPS spectrum (Fig. 6a), Fe, O and C existed simultaneously on the surface of FeOx-500, and the content of each element were 23.87 %, 48.19 % and 27.94 %, respectively. Elemental contents of Mn, O and C in MnOx-500 were 22.62 %, 51.47 % and 25.91 %, respectively. While on the surface of Mn2Fe3Ox-500, the contents of Mn, Fe, O and C were 10.21 %, 11.87 %, 53.35 % and 24.58 %, respectively. In the O 1s XPS spectrum of MnOx-500, FeOx-500 and Mn2Fe3Ox-500, the lattice oxygen (Olatt) and surface physics/chemisorption of oxygen (Oads) were appeared at ∼ 529.7 and 531.2 eV, respectively (Fig. 6b). Oads are usually more migratory than Olatt, favoring the catalytic oxidation of VOCs [28]. Rapidly consumed lattice oxygen was continuously supplemented by a large amount of adsorbed oxygen [29]. Adsorbed oxygen actively participates in the catalytic reaction process, which improved the activity of the catalyst. Also, the Oads can roughly represent oxygen vacancies [30]. The higher ratio of Oads/Olatt (0.88) on Mn2Fe3Ox-500 made it contain more chemisorbed oxygen and higher oxygen migration capacity, which facilitated the catalytic reaction of Mn2Fe3Ox-500 for toluene. Fig. 6c showed the Mn 2p XPS spectrum. The asymmetrical Mn 2p3/2 peak of the MnOx-500 featured at the binding energies of ∼644.9, 642.3 and 640.9 eV were assigned to Mn4+, Mn3+ and Mn2+ species. After fitting the Mn 2p3/2 peak of Mn2Fe3Ox-500, the subpeaks at binding energies of ∼ 645.1, 642.1 and 640.9 eV correspond to Mn4+, Mn3+ and Mn2+, respectively [31,32]. The binding energies of Mn4+ and Mn3+ changed after the introduction of Fe into the MnOx-500 catalyst, suggesting possible electron transfer between Mn4+, Mn3+, Fe3+ and Fe2+. The ratio Mn3+/ Mn4+ in MnOx-500 and Mn2Fe3Ox-500 were calculated to be 2.2 and 2.8 respectively. Apparently, the higher content of Mn3+ in the Mn2Fe3-MOF-74 derived Mn2Fe3Ox-500 catalyst indicated that the presence of interactions between Fe and Mn, which are consistence with the H2-TPR results [33]. It had been proved that high concentration of Mn3+ was conducive to the formation of oxygen vacancy and promoted the overall catalytic performance of toluene [20,34,35]. The curves of Fe 2p XPS spectrum were also shown in Fig. 6d. There were two distinct peaks at ∼ 710.0 and 723.8 eV belonging to Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2, respectively. There are two weak peaks at ∼ 731.2 and 718.0 eV in the spectrum corresponding to the companion peaks of the Fe 2p1/2 and Fe 2p3/2 orbital. The Fe 2p3/2 peak of the Mn2Fe3Ox-500 catalyst was divided into two peaks, the peak at ∼ 709.8 eV corresponded to the Fe2+, and the peak at ∼ 711.7 eV corresponded to the Fe3+. The ratio Fe3+/ Fe2+ in Mn2Fe3Ox-500, and FeOx-500 were calculated to be 1.6 and 1.7 respectively, indicating that the Fe species existed mainly in the Fe3+ form. In all, Mn2Fe3Ox-500 catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic performance with abundant Fe3+, Mn3+, and Oads species on the surface. It can be speculated that the promotion of toluene oxidation by Mn2Fe3Ox-500 was due to the synergistic effect between MnOx and FeOx species, which was caused by the interaction of their electronic structures [36]. The C 1s XPS spectrum can be split into three peaks corresponding to the three signals C=C/C-C (284.8 eV), C-OH (286.2 eV) and HO-C=O (288.5 eV) (Fig. 6e). As can be observed from the C 1s peak of the Mn2Fe3Ox-500 catalyst, the spectrum of Mn2Fe3Ox-500 showed an increase in the relative content of C-OH ratio to 32.2 % as compared to FeOx-500, MnOx-500 catalyst, while the relative contents of C=O/C-C and HO-C=O decrease to 56.1 and 11.6 %, demonstrating that the Mn2Fe3Ox-500 catalyst was rich in oxygen-containing functional groups [37]. A large number of oxygen-containing functional groups can play a synergistic role in anchoring the metal atoms, which will directly affect the catalytic effect [38–41]. The redox properties of a catalyst affect its catalytic performance. The redox performance of FeOx-500, MnOx-500 and Mn2Fe3Ox-500 catalysts was investigated using the H2-TPR analysis (Fig. 7 a). The reduction peak of FeOx-500 catalyst appeared at ∼ 436 °C. For MnOx-500 catalyst, only one reduction peak could be observed at ∼ 612 °C, which was probably the result of the reduction of Mn3O4 to MnO [20]. After Fe doping, two reduction peaks could be observed at ∼ 447 and 644 °C. The peak at ∼ 447 °C was the result of the simultaneous reduction of Mn2O3→Mn3O4, Fe2O3→FeO [26]. At ∼ 644 °C, it was assigned to the reduction of Mn3O4 to MnO and FeO to Fe [42,43]. Compared to FeOx-500 and MnOx-500, Mn2Fe3Ox-500 had a lower temperature reduction peak and the redox properties of Mn2Fe3Ox-500 were better, which was more favorable for the catalytic reactions to take place. It was confirmed by H2-TPR that Fe species could enhance the redox ability of MOF derived metal oxide catalysts. The results corresponded to the catalytic performance of Mn2Fe3Ox-500. The better low-temperature reduction of Mn2Fe3Ox-500 was closely related to its enhanced catalytic activity. For O2-TPD analysis, different oxygen species on FeOx-500, MnOx-500 and Mn2Fe3Ox-500 catalysts were studied (Fig. 7b). Generally, there were two main temperature regions for O2 desorption: below 150 °C and above 150 °C. The low- and high- temperature regions can be related to the type of oxygen [35]. Compared with the O2-TPD spectrum of FeOx-500 and MnOx-500 sample, one Oads peak could be observed at ∼ 130 °C in Mn2Fe3Ox-500, more surface adsorbed oxygen existed in Mn2Fe3Ox-500, which facilitated performance. Additionally, the desorption peak area of Olatt was significantly increased in Mn2Fe3Ox-500, indicating the presence of more abundant oxygen species in Mn2Fe3Ox-500. O2-TPD results confirmed that the active surface lattice oxygen increased with Fe doping. Moreover, more abundant surface oxygen species played a positive role in promoting the degradation of toluene on the Mn2Fe3Ox-500 surface. The intermediates and degradation pathways of the catalytic oxidation reaction of toluene were investigated using in-situ DRIFTS to explore possible mechanisms. First, the adsorption of toluene on Mn2Fe3Ox-500 catalyst was observed at 50 °C (Fig. 8 ). In the 1000-3500 cm−1 range, the characteristic peaks of toluene and CO2 appeared. The typical skeleton ν (C-H) stretching vibration peak (∼ 3036 cm−1) of toluene and the stretching vibration peak (∼ 2365 cm−1) of CO2 appeared [44]. Few intermediates and end products were detected at low temperature, suggesting that the Mn2Fe3Ox-500 was relatively stable at low temperature, and difficult to oxidize. Typically, the reaction mechanism of VOCs oxidation included Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism, Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism and Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism. The current research generally believes that it is possible to explain the degradation of VOCs over metal oxide catalysts by the MvK mechanism [45]. Olatt reacted with the molecules of VOCs on the catalyst surface, and the subsequent oxygen vacancies created were replenished by gaseous oxygen, thus continuing the cycle allowing the catalytic oxidation reaction to continue [30]. By in-situ DRIFTS experiments, it revealed the mechanism of toluene degradation over Mn2Fe3Ox-500 catalyst. The in-situ DRIFTS of Mn2Fe3Ox-500 catalyst to toluene/N2 and toluene/N2/O2 was carried out at different temperatures. After toluene/N2 adsorption on the catalyst surface, some characteristic peaks were observed (Fig. 9 (a and b)). The peaks observed at ∼ 1594 and 1486 cm−1 were C=C stretching vibration. The peak at ∼ 3069 was the stretching vibration of phenylic C-H, and the peaks at ∼ 3031 cm−1 was the vibration of asymmetric methyl group. The peak at ∼ 1233 cm−1 was thought to be the C-O bonding vibrational peak of the phenolic species on the catalyst surface, indicating that phenol was formed from toluene during the oxidation reaction. It was obvious that with the passage of time, the gradual adsorption of toluene on the catalyst surface increased the peak strength of toluene [46–48]. In addition, all online DRIFTS displayed the end product CO2 appear around ∼ 2360 and 2338 cm−1, which was probably produced by the lattice oxygen reaction of toluene and catalyst [49]. The spectral peak at ∼ 1025 cm−1 started to appear at 200 °C and was a characteristic peak for alcohols. Toluene could interact with active oxygen to form benzyl species. At ∼ 1669 cm−1, the peak was considered to be the (C=O) stretching vibration peak of the alkoxide species, indicating that benzaldehyde was an important class of intermediate product. The peak at ∼ 1406 cm−1 was to the C-O stretching vibration peak of benzoic acid, and benzoic acid was the intermediate of toluene degradation on Mn2Fe3Ox-500 catalyst [50]. The (C-C) stretching vibrational peaks of the formic acid species (-COO) were observed at ∼ 1180 and 1451 cm−1, indicating that the benzene ring had been completely disrupted. The characteristic peak of maleic anhydride appeared at ∼ 1316 cm−1. The results indicated that key intermediates, such as benzyl alcohol, phenol, maleic anhydride, benzaldehyde, benzoic acid, were still detected in the absence of O2. Moreover, it was shown that the Olatt was involved in the degradation of intermediates such as benzoic acid during the degradation of adsorbed toluene [51]. With the introduction of 20 vol.% O2, all peaks increased in intensity, indicating O2 promoted the oxidative degradation reaction of toluene (Fig. 9a). The characteristic peaks of toluene from ∼ 3036 and 3074 cm−1 become progressively weaker with increasing temperature, indicating that toluene was slowly and oxidized to H2O and CO2. A weak vibrational peak (∼ 1156 cm−1) related to stretching vibration of the C-O was observed, indicating the formation of benzoyl oxides (C6H5-CH2-O) on the catalyst surface. The ∼ 1509 cm−1 peak occurred as the temperature rose to 200 °C, representing the maleic anhydride substance, indicating that the benzene ring of toluene had started to break [52–54]. The peak attributed to maleic anhydride became stronger as the temperature increased. And the (C-C) stretching vibration peak of the formic acid species (-COO) was observed at ∼ 1547 cm−1, indicating that the benzene ring had been completely disrupted [55]. Therefore, the pathway of toluene degradation on Mn2Fe3Ox-500 was proposed as shown in Fig. 10 . 4 Conclusions In this work, the bimetallic MnFe-MOF-74 was successfully converted to MnFeOx catalyst by in-situ pyrolysis for the removal of toluene. The Mn2Fe3Ox-500 catalyst with exceptional performance was obtained by adjusting the preparation parameters such as the molar ratio of Mn/Fe, calcination conditions. Mn2Fe3Ox-500 also performed outstanding catalytic durability at high water vapor content and over 36 h of continuous reaction. Superior catalytic performance and durability of the Mn2Fe3Ox-500 catalyst in toluene removal is inextricably linked to its good low-temperature reducibility, abundant Oads species, high concentration of Mn3+/ Mn4+ and strong interaction between Mn and Fe species. Besides, the in-situ DRIFTS results indicated both Oads and Olatt can be involved in the catalytic oxidation of toluene. During the degradation process, maleic anhydride, benzaldehyde, benzyl alcohol, and benzoic acid were produced, and finally converted to H2O and CO2. In all, this work showed that the use of MOFs-derived bimetallic oxide catalysts could effectively eliminate toluene pollutants through catalytic oxidation technology, which provided theoretical and experimental basis for air pollution control in the actual environment. coredata.dc:description: For VOCs oxidation technology, significant room for enhancement still exists in terms of catalytic performance of commonly used transition metal oxide-based catalysts. In this work, we designed MnFeOx oxides catalysts by using in situ pyrolysis of MnFe bimetallic MOF-74 as efficient and stable catalysts for toluene oxidation and this bimetallic framework was synthesized by metal doping. The preferred Mn2Fe3Ox-500 (Mn/Fe molar ratio of 2:3, calcination T=500 °C) catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic activity and stability towards toluene which was significantly superior the control MnOx-500 catalyst. Under simulated industrial real-exhaust conditions, the Mn2Fe3Ox-500 catalyst maintained better resistance at higher air velocities, in addition to exhibiting excellent stability and good water resistance. The superior toluene oxidation activity of Mn2Fe3Ox-500 catalyst can be associated with its high reducibility of metal active species, abundance of oxygen species, and the well dispersion of Fe2O3 and MnOx species. In addition, suggested potential degradation pathways for toluene over the Mn2Fe3Ox-500 catalyst. For the exhaust gas purification industry, this work will be beneficial in exploring the mechanistic level of MOF materials in the field of VOCs removal.
coredata.dc:title: Efficient oxidation and stable removal of toluene over controlled metal-organic framework derived MnFeOx catalysts
